image.altText: A man standing outside a building and smiling grimly.

props.synopsis: The homes in Bellamack were found to be riddled with defects such as water leaks and cracked tiles, making them unsafe during severe weather.

title.children: Builder of defective Darwin homes loses appeal, still owes more than $2.7m to homeowners

image.altText: Unidentified male adult walks hand in hand with child

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government has agreed to pay redress to victims of child sexual abuse in sporting institutions, ending a stalemate between states, territories and the federal government.

title.children: Victims of child abuse in sports around the country set to get compensation under new deal

image.altText: The outside of Crocosaurus Cove

props.synopsis: Police say two children under the age of 10 are believed to have broken into the reptile park, killing two turtles and injuring four others.

title.children: Two turtles killed, four others injured after break-in at popular Darwin tourist attraction

image.altText: A woman in glasses looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: The financial regulator has taken action against a clothing retailer over concerns the store disputes about exposing vulnerable Aboriginal customers to financial risk.

title.children: ASIC orders NT clothing store to stop letting customers pay through Centrelink deductions

image.altText: A dark-haired woman in a dimly lit room.

props.synopsis: A federal Labor MP has flagged that the Commonwealth could take control of an Aboriginal art gallery project in Alice Springs and described the Northern Territory government's plan to downsize the building "offensive".

title.children: 'Size matters': MP flags possible federal government involvement as Indigenous art gallery saga continues

image.altText: A bushmaster vehicle with missile launches attached to the top.

props.synopsis: The Albanese government has approved a tender process that will pit the StrikeMaster mobile missile launcher against the American-made High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS), currently being used by Ukrainian forces.

title.children: Bushmaster missile launchers with a range of 250 kilometres could soon be in place across the Top End

image.altText: NT Police Commissioner Michael Murphy standing at a lectern and looking up.

props.synopsis: NT Police Commissioner Michael Murphy flies into the remote community of Milikapiti on Melville Island after three officers were attacked during an arrest, leaving one unconscious.

title.children: NT police commissioner flies into remote community after officers attacked

image.altText: Emergency sign at Kalgoorlie Health Campus

props.synopsis: According to data from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, patients are waiting longer in public emergency departments to see a doctor.

title.children: Sick people are waiting longer in public hospital emergency departments, but less time for elective surgery

image.altText: A person holds up twom air conditioner filters. One is clean and the other is covered in dust.

props.synopsis: Cleaning your air conditioner's filters is a simple yet often overlooked task. And it is an important one that can not only improve your general wellbeing, but also save you money on energy costs.

title.children: How — and why — you should clean your air conditioner's filters this summer

image.altText: Map of California coast

props.synopsis: A tsunami warning impacting nearly 5 million people after a magnitude-7.0 earthquake on the United States west coast has been lifted.

title.children: Tsunami warning lifted after magnitude-7.0 earthquake in northern California

image.altText: A man wearing a hoodie on CCTV, smiling as he leans against a counter.

props.synopsis: Multiple US media organisations, citing unnamed investigators, say the ammunition used to shoot the UnitedHealth chief executive had the words "deny," "defend" and "depose" written on them.

title.children: Words reportedly written onto ammunition found at scene of health insurance CEO's killing

image.altText: A view from under a thermometer looking up towards the sun in a blue cloudy sky

props.synopsis: Last year eclipsed predicted temperatures. Now a new study suggests the extra warming occurred when the Earth became less reflective due to a drop in low cloud cover.

title.children: Disappearing clouds could have contributed to hottest year on record

image.altText: Storm clouds over Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Thunderstorms are likely to hit Australia's south-east over the weekend as "very humid" weather normally felt in the Far North takes hold, the Bureau of Meteorology warns.

title.children: Severe thunderstorms forecast for parts of south-eastern Australia amid 'very humid' weather

image.altText: A man in a business shirt and suit jacket sits in a chair in an office, looking serious as he's interviewed for television.

props.synopsis: Following a three-month external review, the NSW government found there was no basis to proceed with misconduct proceedings against John Minns.

title.children: NSW Strata Commissioner John Minns cleared of misconduct following Four Corners investigation

image.altText: A composite image of a man in a suit and a woman wearing glasses.

props.synopsis: It's no secret the government is impatient for a rate cut, and frustrated we're not seeing one. But it can't say so, because that would invite attacks it was pressuring the independent bank.

title.children: Frustrated government can only bite its tongue as it waits on Michele Bullock

image.altText: Man in dark suit standing talking.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton said the quiet part out loud this week when asked why he was taking so long to release his nuclear costings.

title.children: When Dutton was asked about his nuclear drip-feed, he said the quiet part out loud

image.altText: Two large gold coins bearing engraved "b"s lie on top of a complex financial line-and-bar graph

props.synopsis: It's a wild ride for crypto prices, with volatility for Bitcoin after it surpassed $US100,000. The local share market has fallen, while Woolworths is attempting to end strike action affecting its supply chain. Follow the day's events and insights on our live markets blog.

title.children: Bitcoin price volatile after hitting record, ASX in the red

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Woolworths applies to move on picket lines
Wall Street falls ahead of jobs report

image.altText: A North Korean woman in her 30s helps a North Korean man in his 30 sign a document

props.synopsis: News of an unfolding political crisis in South Korea dominated global headlines. But just over the border, North Koreans are kept in the dark. How will the hermit kingdom's leaders respond?

title.children: Why has North Korea stayed silent about South Korea's political crisis?

image.altText: a young man and young woman hype up the crowd on the stage of a Christian youth camp

props.synopsis: New Australian research has found that young men are identifying as Christian and seeing the benefits of organised religion at much higher rates than women of the same generation.

title.children: 'Belonging, worth and identity': Why more Australian Gen Z men are finding meaning in organised religion

image.altText: A man pushes the button on a washing machine that's full of clothes

props.synopsis: Your washing machine may not use much energy, but how long will it last and can it be fixed easily if it breaks? Advocates say knowing the answers to those questions could help buyers see through deceptive marketing.

title.children: Consumer advocates call for new rating system to fight appliance 'greenwashing'

image.altText: Close up of two hands, palms facing upward, under a tap with running water in a sink.

props.synopsis: Water scientist Dr Ian Wright says if Sydney Water, the state's largest supplier, can fail to detect contamination like what was found in the Upper Blue Mountains in June, then it could happen anywhere.

title.children: Experts raise alarm over PFAS testing approach between city and country

image.altText: A man in a suit stands in front of artworks mid sentence.

props.synopsis: Former Defence Department secretary Dennis Richardson has been asked to oversee the structure and provide advice on the direction of the Australian Submarine Agency.

title.children: Agency overseeing $368 billion AUKUS program to be examined amid concerns over its performance

image.altText: Large billboard of man with politcal slogans

props.synopsis: The Making Queensland Safer Bill will be debated in state parliament next week after going through a fast-tracked committee process.

title.children: 'Adult crime, adult time' policy expected to get green light after week of scrutiny

image.altText: A court sketch of a man in a suit in a witness dock

props.synopsis: The former partner of a popular social media influencer is found guilty of murdering his mother as part of a plan to claim life insurance policies he had taken out on her.

title.children: Man whose mother was found dead in her shower after he took out life insurance policies in her name guilty of murder

image.altText: Copper wiring bundles into circles

props.synopsis: Five sporting clubs are the latest victims of the rising crime of copper theft, with the removal of 400 metres of copper wiring destroying a popular recreation reserve's power supply.

title.children: Copper thieves destroy major sporting ground power supply as high metal price drives crime rise

image.altText: The aisle of a plane's cabin.

props.synopsis: Thousands of people with food allergies experience high levels of anxiety when flying, and don't report reactions that happen mid-journey, according to a global survey.

title.children: Survey reveals many food-related allergic reactions on flights go unreported

image.altText: quix pic

props.synopsis: Righto then smarty pants, think you've been paying attention to the news this week? Test yourself.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: An ATM fee, a win for the Matildas and Australia's most-streamed artist

image.altText: The glow of a computer screen reflecyed in the pupil of a woman's eye.

props.synopsis: The chronic and progressive disease is being found in younger Australians with children as young as 12 developing symptoms.

title.children: Screen time among digital natives could be causing a disease traditionally associated with 'older' people

image.altText: CCTV vision of an old man wearing a face mask and wearing a hat and casual attire.

props.synopsis: A CCTV image has been released of a man police believe can assist in their investigation into several explosions and a fire that occurred at offices on the NSW Central Coast.

title.children: CCTV image released as police investigate several explosions and fire at offices in Gosford CBD

image.altText: A woman with teal and black hair, wearing red lipstick and blue graphic eyeliner looks into a small makeup mirror, smiling.

props.synopsis: Organisers of two LGBTQIA+ festival events in regional Australia say they were targeted online with abusive comments, forcing them to hire security and replace performers. Feast Festival's CEO has called on the state government to offer better legal protection for the community. SA's Attorney-General says the government is open to looking at the matter.

title.children: Online abuse prompts performers to drop out of regional burlesque and drag show

image.altText: A public bus with a wrap on the back that reads "MyWay+".

props.synopsis: Speaking to Stateline, ACT Chief Minister Andrew Barr concedes the government should have waited several more days before rolling out a new public transport ticketing system that was plagued with problems as it went live.

title.children: ACT government concedes it should have postponed MyWay+ rollout by at least a week

image.altText: One troops blocks their ears while another sets up what looks like a long missile.

props.synopsis: Ukraine says the body of a mayor captured by Russian forces at the start of their invasion has been returned, while its security service has detained a 16-year-old girl accused of helping Moscow orchestrate an air strike.

title.children: Ukraine says mayor who was jailed by Russia died after torture

image.altText: A post-impressionist painting of a crowded Australian beach.

props.synopsis: At first glance artists Ethel Carrick and Anne Dangar seem to have little in common besides gender and career choice, but a new exhibition at the National Gallery of Australia is inviting visitors to take a closer look.

title.children: Two 'important yet under-acknowledged' women artists celebrated in National Gallery of Australia exhibition
